question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find all values of $k,$ for which there exists a nonzero vector $\mathbf{v}$ such that
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & -3 & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{v} = k \mathbf{v}.\]
inference:
**Solution:**
The equation can be written as
\[\left(\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & -3 & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & 0 \end{pmatrix} - kI\right) \mathbf{v} = \mathbf{0}.\]

The matrix on the left is singular if and only if its determinant is zero. So, we have
\[\begin{vmatrix} 2-k & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & -3-k & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & -k \end{vmatrix} = 0.\]

Expanding along the first row, we get
\[(2-k)\begin{vmatrix} -3-k & 2 \\ 2 & -k \end{vmatrix} - (-2)\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ -1 & -k \end{vmatrix} + 1\begin{vmatrix} 2 & -3-k \\ -1 & 2 \end{vmatrix} = 0.\]

Evaluating the determinants, we get
\[(2-k)((-3-k)(-k) - 2(2)) + 2(2(-k) - (-1)(2)) + 1(2(2) - (-1)(-3-k)) = 0.\]

Simplifying, we get
\[(2-k)(k^2 + 3k - 4) + 4(k+1) + 3(k+5) = 0.\]

Expanding and combining like terms, we get
\[k^3 - k^2 - 10k + 8 + 4k + 4 + 3k + 15 = 0.\]

Simplifying further, we get
\[k^3 - k^2 - 3k + 27 = 0.\]

Factoring, we get
\[(k-3)(k^2 + 2k - 9) = 0.\]

So, the solutions are $k = 3$ and $k = -3 \pm 2\sqrt{3}$.

**Final Answer: \\boxed{$k = 3, -3 \pm 2\sqrt{3}$}. I hope it is correct.**
ground_truth:
We can write the equation as
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & -3 & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{v} = k \mathbf{I} \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} k & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & k & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & k \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{v}.\]Then
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - k & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & -3 - k & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & -k \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{v} = \mathbf{0}.\]This equation has a nonzero vector $\mathbf{v}$ as a solution if and only if
\[\begin{vmatrix} 2 - k & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & -3 - k & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & -k \end{vmatrix} = 0.\]Expanding this determinant, we get
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 2 - k & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & -3 - k & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & -k \end{vmatrix} &= (2 - k) \begin{vmatrix} -3 - k & 2 \\ 2 & -k \end{vmatrix} - (-2) \begin{vmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ -1 & -k \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 2 & -3 - k \\ -1 & 2 \end{vmatrix} \\
&= (2 - k)((-3 - k)(-k) - (2)(2)) -(-2) ((2)(-k) - (2)(-1)) + ((2)(2) - (-3 - k)(-1)) \\
&= -k^3 - k^2 + 5k - 3.
\end{align*}Thus, $k^3 + k^2 - 5k + 3 = 0.$  This equation factors as $(k - 1)^2 (k + 3) = 0,$ so the possible values of $k$ are $\boxed{1, -3}.$

Note that for $k = 1,$ we can take $\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and for $k = -3,$ we can take $\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ -2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.$

ground_truth:
We can write the equation as
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & -3 & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{v} = k \mathbf{I} \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} k & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & k & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & k \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{v}.\]Then
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - k & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & -3 - k & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & -k \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{v} = \mathbf{0}.\]This equation has a nonzero vector $\mathbf{v}$ as a solution if and only if
\[\begin{vmatrix} 2 - k & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & -3 - k & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & -k \end{vmatrix} = 0.\]Expanding this determinant, we get
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 2 - k & -2 & 1 \\ 2 & -3 - k & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & -k \end{vmatrix} &= (2 - k) \begin{vmatrix} -3 - k & 2 \\ 2 & -k \end{vmatrix} - (-2) \begin{vmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ -1 & -k \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 2 & -3 - k \\ -1 & 2 \end{vmatrix} \\
&= (2 - k)((-3 - k)(-k) - (2)(2)) -(-2) ((2)(-k) - (2)(-1)) + ((2)(2) - (-3 - k)(-1)) \\
&= -k^3 - k^2 + 5k - 3.
\end{align*}Thus, $k^3 + k^2 - 5k + 3 = 0.$  This equation factors as $(k - 1)^2 (k + 3) = 0,$ so the possible values of $k$ are $\boxed{1, -3}.$

Note that for $k = 1,$ we can take $\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and for $k = -3,$ we can take $\mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ -2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.$
